summary: Since its entry into the Chinese-language world in 2000, U.S. search giant Google Inc. has struggled to balance its growth ambitious in the vast but restrictive new market while adhering to a self-held principle: "Don't be evil."

summary: Examples of "Chinglish," or mistranslated English, in the Chinese town of Changzhou.

summary: Police responding to a call about an unconscious woman in Crown Heights early Sunday morning found what appeared to be a murder-suicide, police said.

headline: Treasury Plans $61 Billion In Security Sales
summary: The Treasury plans to sell $61 billion in securities this week.

headline: China, Taiwan Sign Trade Pact
summary: Taiwan and China signed a wide-ranging trade agreement that will reduce tariffs on hundreds of petrochemical, textile and other items and open services including banking to cross-strait investment.

headline: Coke Hopes to Score With  Campaign
summary: Coca-Cola has provided World Cup gear to 1,000 South African restaurants and taverns and sponsored a World Cup trophy tour through 84 countries as it sees the tournament as a chance to build on its Africa business.

headline: South Korea to Move Government Offices
summary: South Korean lawmakers voted to move half of the national government to a city being built south of Seoul, rejecting President Lee's effort to keep the government together.

headline: Consumer Confidence Tumbled in June
summary: U.S. consumer confidence dropped sharply in June to 52.9, amid concerns over the sustainability of recovery. Separately, U.S. home prices rose in April, boosted by the expiration of a tax credit.

headline: Hon Hai Evaluates China Expansion
summary: Taiwan's Hon Hai Precision Industry said it is evaluating several expansion projects in China's inland provinces as the company aims to meet growing demand for its products

headline: Andreessen Horowitz Leads Foursquare Investment
summary: Foursquare, a mobile-based startup that lets people "check in" at bars, restaurants and other places through their smartphones, has raised $20 million from a group of venture capitalists that will help fuel its expansion.

headline: Spain's Telefonica Raises Bid For Vivo Stake
summary: Spain's Telefonica raised its offer for a stake in Brazil's Vivo Participacioes to €7.15 billion ($8.78 billion), in a last-ditch attempt to win over shareholders of Portugal Telecom.

headline: U.S. Names New Ambassador to Venezuela
summary: U.S. President Barack Obama has nominated a new ambassador to Venezuela, a move the outgoing envoy said might lead to a "new phase" for relations between the two countries, which have been strained for years.

headline: Congress Seeks More Toyota Documents
summary: The U.S. House committee has asked Toyota Motor to produce more documents related to unintended acceleration by July 6.

headline: Greater New York Watch
summary: Summary of regional news

headline: Chelsea With a Flemish Bite
summary: Markt in Chelsea serves Belgian cuisine, an assortment of mussels and a wide selection of Belgian beers in a relaxed and upscale environment.

headline: Currency Reservations
summary: None

headline: Deloitte CEO Seeks Acquisitions
summary: Deloitte is looking to make acquisitions to beef up as the business climate improves.

headline: Deal Reached to Save 77 Detroit Parks
summary: Detroit's city council reached an agreement with the mayor on budget cuts that is expected to save 77 public parks that had been slated for closure.

headline: Pictures of the Day: June 29
summary: In today's photos, a riot police officer clashes with a protester in Spain, farmers play in the mud in Nepal, a boy becomes Spider-Man in England and more.

headline: A Unique Side of Moore
summary: By focusing on smaller works,Tate Britain's retrospective of Henry Moore offers an intimate portrayal of an artist better known for his large-scale bronzes.

headline: House Effort to Extend Jobless Benefits Falters
summary: A House measure to extend federal jobless benefits for six months failed as a majority of House Republicans opposed the extension, citing its cost.

headline: The NCMA's New Wing
summary: At the North Carolina Museum of Art in Raleigh, the newly opened West Building adds 127,000-square-feet of exhibition space, as well as sculpture gardens, to the museum. The $72.3 million expansion was funded entirely by state, county and Raleigh city funds. Here's a look.

headline: J.P. Morgan Offers Small Businesses Rate Cuts If They Hire
summary: The U.S.'s second-biggest bank will lower the interest rate charged on a line of credit to small-business customers by half a percentage point for every new hire they make, for up to three hires.

headline: Housing's Fragile States
summary: Some of America's hardest-hit housing markets still have legs. Or so it appeared Tuesday, when a report showed healthy price increases in some states where valuations had fallen the most.

headline: Options Traders Make Beeline to Bearish ETFs
summary: The Chicago Board Options Exchange's volatility index, or VIX, rose as much as 22% in the session and closed up nearly 18%.

headline: World Cup: June 29
summary: Paraguay beats Japan in a shootout and Spain gets past Portugal, 1-0.

headline: Kagan Confirmation Hearings: Day Two
summary: Supreme Court nominee Elena Kagan on Tuesday vigorously defended her position on military recruiting while dean at Harvard Law School, saying she is a strong supporter of the military and never barred its officers from recruiting on campus.

headline: Global Growth Fears Hit U.S. Markets
summary: Fears about the pace of global growth hit financial markets hard, with stocks sliding and investors stampeding into the safety of the dollar and U.S. government bonds.

headline: Hitachi Shifts From Electronics to Infrastructure
summary: Hitachi, one of Japan's largest companies by revenue, is reshaping itself and pinning long-term growth on a broad swath of operations including infrastructure projects and data centers.

headline: Molson Coors Enters Russian Market With Coors Light Brand
summary: Molson Coors Brewing Co. is entering the Russian market with its Coors Light brand, continuing the brewer's push for growth overseas.

headline: European, Asian Stocks Take a Tumble
summary: Fears about the pace of global growth hit financial markets hard Tuesday as U.K. stocks hit a 2010 low and Chinese shares led an Asian tumble.

headline: New Securities Issues
summary: The following were among recent offerings and pricings in U.S. and non-U.S. capital markets, with terms and syndicate manager, based on information provided by Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva.

headline: Crude Tumbles Below $76
summary: Crude-oil futures fell sharply as investors avoided commodities and other assets seen as risks amid continued indications of a sluggish economic recovery.

headline: Gold Prices Turn Positive
summary: Gold futures eked out slight gains while growth-sensitive markets capitulated to fears about a faltering world-wide economic recovery.

headline: Big Payouts Set at GLG
summary: Several GLG employees stand to get millions of dollars in compensation under changes to their contracts made the day before the company's purchase by Man Group was announced in May.

headline: Markets Drop as Economies On Their Own
summary: Sliding global market sentiment -- resulting in dramatic stock and bond price movements Tuesday -- demonstrates investors' shock of recognition that there's no one left to help.

headline: The Petraeus Papers
summary: OK, no more magazine interviews, and that's an order.

headline: Emerson Raises Chloride Bid
summary: Emerson sweetened its offer to buy Chloride to $1.5 billion, after the U.K. secure-power-systems company rebuffed an earlier bid and backed a better deal from Switzerland's ABB.

headline: BBC Pension Gets Less Generous
summary: The BBC is set to close its generous defined-benefit pension scheme to new joiners, as the pensions cuts that have already swept through the country's private sector begin to toll on state employees.

headline: EDF CEO Says No Decision on U.K. Grid
summary: EDF CEO Henri Proglio is still undecided on whether to sell the company's U.K.-based power distribution unit EDF Energy, even though the sale process is well underway, he said in an interview.

headline: Sprint CEO Sees Spot Shortages in Evo Phones
summary: Sprint Nextel Corp. Chief Executive Dan Hesse said he continues to see "spot shortages" of the company's flagship Evo 4G smartphone at some of its stores.

headline: Romanian Leu Hits New Low
summary: Reassurances that an austerity package meant a second tranche of IMF funds was likely to come wasn't enough to stem investors' fears over an economic contraction.

headline: Stock Markets Flashing Warning Signals
summary: Stocks seem to be interpreting the business environment as a warning of a coming double-dip recession.

headline: And Now, the Tricky Part: Naming Your Business
summary: Getting a start-up off the ground is easy, compared with conjuring up the perfect moniker. Experts recommend short, snappy and easy to spell.

headline: Overlooked Dutch Remain Unbeaten
summary: The Netherlands beat Slovakia 2-1 to continue their quietly dominant World Cup play.

headline: FAA Proposes Tougher Icing Rules
summary: Federal regulators on Tuesday proposed tougher icing rules for new airliner models.

headline: U.S. Charges 11 in Russian Spy Case
summary: Authorities charged 11 people with belonging to a long-running Russian program to plant secret agents inside the U.S.

headline: AXA's Shrink-to-Grow Strategy
summary: For a company with a reputation for frenetic deal-making, AXA is revealing a more measured side.

headline: Accor Holders Vote to Split Company
summary: Shareholders of hotels and vouchers group Accor voted to proceed with the split of the group into two separately listed companies.

headline: Luanda Tops Priciest Expat Cities
summary: Luanda, the capital of oil-rich but poverty-stricken Angola, is the world's most expensive city for expatriates, according to a new survey  by consulting firm Mercer.

headline: European Markets Tumble
summary: European stocks tumbled, nearing their lows for the year as fears grew that the global recovery is petering out.

headline: Euro-Zone Consumer Confidence Grows
summary: The fiscal crisis that threatens the euro zone failed to dent the confidence of consumers and most businesses during June, boosting hopes that the currency area's economic recovery will continue.

headline: WPP Reiterates Forecast
summary: WPP, the ad agency holding company, reiterated that it expects to post around 2% organic revenue growth this year as advertising markets continue to improve.

headline: VAT Strains U.K. Coalition
summary: The U.K.'s planned increase in the value-added tax rate has produced the clearest fissure yet between the Liberal Democrats and Conservative Party that make up the nation's new ruling coalition

headline: AgBank Discounts Risk on Government-Backed Loans
summary: Agricultural Bank of China, moving to reassure investors ahead of its huge share offering, played down the threat of deteriorating local-government credit to its profitability.

headline: Japan's NKSJ Plans Acquisitions
summary: NKSJ, the parent of nonlife insurer Sompo Japan,  will keep searching for overseas partners after buying a Turkish nonlife insurer, as it and its Japanese counterparts look for expansion opportunities abroad to counter the challenges posed by Japan's shrinking and aging population.

headline: Petraeus Takes the Stand
summary: Gen. David Petraeus testified Tuesday before Senate Armed Services Committee, which is expected to recommend the full Senate swiftly confirm him as leader of the U.S. military effort in Afghanistan.

headline: Worthington Industries, Wainwright Bank & Trust: Biggest Price Gainers (WOR, WAIN)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Dismal U.S., China Data Hits Copper
summary: Copper futures slumped as disappointing economic data from Asia and the U.S. painted a bleak picture of demand for the industrial metal.

headline: Ryanair Cuts U.K. Winter Capacity
summary: Ryanair said it will cut U.K. winter capacity because of the British government's departure tax and high airport charges, resulting in the loss of 200 jobs at the budget carrier.

headline: High Court Rejects Pfizer Appeal In Nigeria Drug-Trial Case
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court refused to consider Pfizer's challenge to a pair of lawsuits alleging that the drug maker illegally tested an antibiotic drug on Nigerian children in 1996.

headline: Court Backs EU Limits on De Beers
summary: The European Commission scored a victory in a legal tussle with Russian diamond producer Alrosa as Europe's highest court upheld a commitment made by De Beers to halt purchases of uncut gems from the Russian supplier.

headline: Rival Files SAP Complaint
summary: Versata, a unit of closely held Trilogy, filed an antitrust complaint with the European Commission against Germany's SAP, alleging it has abused its dominant position in the enterprise software market.

headline: White House Unveils Space Goals
summary: The Obama administration's move to significantly expand cooperation with other countries in space comes as likely foreign partners appear increasingly ready to embrace the same strategy.

headline: Japan 10-Year Yield at 7-Year Low
summary: The benchmark 10-year Japanese government bond yield dropped to a seven-year low, as a sharp appreciation of the yen darkened the nation's export-reliant economy and prodded investors to pile into safe-haven assets.

headline: 'Potential Errors' Delay U.K. GDP Data
summary: The final reading of U.K. domestic-product data, which was scheduled for this week, has now been delayed by almost two weeks owing to "potential errors."

headline: Sarbox Survives Mostly Intact
summary: The Supreme Court's ruling on the Sarbanes-Oxley law means big U.S. companies will have to continue complying with a law that many they have long criticized as overly burdensome.

headline: Global Airline Traffic Jumps
summary: International air-passenger traffic soared 12% in May, rebounding from the chaos in April when clouds of volcanic ash caused massive disruption in Europe.

headline: India PM: To Lift Control on Diesel Prices
summary: Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh said the federal government will fully deregulate diesel prices, as the south Asian country continues to reform its fuel sector and lift pressure on the government's finances.

headline: H-P, Avaya Sign 3-Year Deal
summary: H-P and Avaya signed a three-year agreement to add some of the communications-systems company's products to H-P's portfolio.

headline: FSA Supervisory Director to Leave
summary: Jon Pain, managing director of supervision at the U.K.'s FSA, will leave the regulator next year amid a regulatory overhaul.

headline: China's Landslide Traps Over 100
summary: A landslide triggered by heavy rains trapped at least 107 people, with little hope of survival, in China's southwest Guizhou province.

headline: U.K. Money Supply Grows
summary: The BOE's preferred measure of broad money supply growth picked up to a near three-year high in May, but lending to households and businesses marked their lowest annual rates in decades.

headline: Reliance Capital Asset to Launch Islamic Funds
summary: The Malaysian unit of Reliance Capital Asset Management plans to launch its two maiden Shariah-compliant funds as it seeks to tap into Malaysia's importance as a Shariah-compliant financial hub and the growing demand for Islamic funds from the region.

headline: Srinagar Standoff
summary: Srinagar remained shut Tuesday as the city witnessed protests over the death of three civilians in a clash over the weekend. Some snapshots.

headline: Steel Authority Share Sale May Be Delayed
summary: State-run Steel Authority of India's proposed share sale may be delayed by a month to November as the board needs to add more independent directors to meet a key corporate governance rule, said federal Steel Secretary Atul Chaturvedi.

headline: Pope Rebukes Prominent Austrian Cardinal
summary: Pope Benedict XVI sought to quell discord within church ranks Monday, publicly scolding a prominent cardinal who criticized the Vatican's handling of sex-abuse cases under Pope John Paul II.

headline: China Stocks Lead Asia Lower
summary: China shares fell 3.7%, pushing other Asian markets down, on economic slowdown concerns both globally and at home.

headline: Officials Indicate RBI May Not Raise Rates Soon
summary: Two senior officials--one from the central bank and the other the country's chief statistician--made statements suggesting that the Reserve Bank of India may not opt for an inter-meeting interest rate increase.

headline: India Gold Imports Likely Down 40%
summary: India's gold imports will likely fall 40% in 2010 from 343 metric tons last year as prices climb to new highs, Bombay Bullion Association President Suresh Hundia said.

headline: Prayers for Rain
summary: India's monsoon has halted for a second time this month as the progress of the rain-carrying winds has been delayed. Snapshots of prayers being offered and rituals performed to please the rain gods.

headline: A Face Lift for ULIPs
summary: Another set of rules improves these plans but they're still more expensive than mutual funds, says Shefali Anand, India personal finance writer.

headline: GM Touts New Cars, Growth Markets
summary: General Motors pitched itself to potential investors Tuesday, outlining a global strategy that hinges on a string of new cars and growth in developing nations.

headline: The Prostate Cancer Quandary
summary: Scientists may soon be able to answer the agonizing question facing men with prostate cancer: Does their cancer need immediate treatment or can it be left alone?

headline: Panetta's Bomb
summary: Now the CIA tells us that Iran is going nuclear, and sanctions won't work.

headline: MoMA Attendance Hits Record High
summary: What do you get when you combine a mischievous filmmaker, a cache of floral masterpieces and a handful of nude performers? A record box office.

headline: At Vassar College, Summer Is for the Stage
summary: Tony winners of tomorrow begin new season at Poughkeepsie company.

headline: FDA Warns on Antibiotics in Livestock
summary: The FDA, worried about the rise of drug-resistant pathogens, stepped up its campaign to discourage the use of human antibiotics in farm animals.

headline: The Curious Case of iPhone 4
summary: If the iPhone 4 has become "the most successful product launch in Apple's history," as the company says, one wouldn't want to imagine the worst.

headline: Diagnosing Several Disorders
summary: Health columnist Melinda Beck answers readers' questions on her column about diagnosing the emotional problems of fictional characters, and more.

headline: Abbott Puts Unit Up for Sale
summary: Abbott Laboratories is seeking a buyer for the flu-vaccine business it picked up in its recent purchase of Solvay's pharmaceutical unit, in a deal people familiar with the matter said could be worth $619 million.

headline: European Firms Increase Focus on Asia
summary: An HSBC study, titled assesses the implications of the rise of Asia for European businesses as they pursue opportunities in a region rich in political turmoil, sudden changes but also fast growth.

headline: May Home Sales Rocket in Connecticut
summary: Sales of Connecticut single-family homes rose at the fastest pace in at least two decades last month while prices were essentially flat.

headline: Fed's Mortgage Plan Lowers Its Sights
summary: The Federal Reserve is having trouble tying up the loose ends of its $1.25 trillion program to buy mortgage-backed securities, prompting an announcement on Monday Monday that it would buy different bonds than originally planned.

headline: Democrats Ditch Finance Overhaul's Bank Tax
summary: Congressional Democrats abandoned a proposed controversial bank tax to pay for the financial overhaul bill in a bid to pull the White House's legislation from the brink of collapse.

headline: 'Entourage' Star Is His Own Man
summary: Although he's famous for his portrayal of a playboy movie star on the HBO series "Entourage," Adrian Grenier has never gone Hollywood. Raised on the Upper West Side, Mr. Grenier remains a New Yorker.

headline: Libraries Have a Novel Idea
summary: Libraries are expanding e-book offerings with out-of-print editions, part of a broader effort to widen borrowing privileges in the Internet Age.

headline: A Modest Start for Kagan
summary: Supreme Court nominee Elena Kagan sought to counter assertions that she is a liberal activist who would bring a political agenda to the court, as confirmation hearings began.

headline: Former Boston Provident Executive Sentenced
summary: Ezra Levy, a former executive of hedge fund Boston Provident, was sentenced to five years and seven months in prison after admitting to embezzling and defrauding the fund out of $3 million.

headline: Weaker Euro Set to Spur Irish Turnaround
summary: A weaker euro may help the Germans sell cars and the Greeks sell island vacations, but Ireland may gain the most, in part because of its  export-driven economy's trade ties with the U.K. and the U.S.

headline: Glaxo's Avandia Cited for Heart Risk
summary: Two new studies said the Glaxo diabetes drug Avandia is unsafe, heating up a controversy about a drug linked in a number of studies to an increased risk of heart attack and heart failure.

headline: No Glass Ceiling for Best Job in World
summary: SABMiller decided to reach deeper into its employee pool to find adept beer tasters, inviting marketers, secretaries and others to try their hand. The company concluded that women were drinking men under the table.

headline: Court Ruling Seen as Challenge to N.Y. Gun Permits
summary: A ruling by the U.S. Supreme Court giving federal judges the power to strike down local weapons laws is expected to prompt legal challenges to New York City's gun-permits process.

headline: Manufacturers in Japan Turn Positive
summary: Sentiment among big manufacturers in Japan unexpectedly turned positive for the first time in two years.

headline: Suspects Blended Into America
summary: From selling real-estate to working in a travel agency, some of the suspects accused of belonging to Russian spy network carried on ordinary lives that didn't raise flags among neighbors or bosses.

headline: Our G-20 Strategy Is Badly Flawed
summary: "Our Agenda for the G-20," an op-ed published in Wednesday's Journal and authored by Treasury Secretary Tim Geitner and Larry Summers which reflects the "government knows best" philosophy which got us into the global debt crisis, and won't get us out of it.

headline: China Investors Feel the Pain
summary: China's 23% stock decline in the second quarter outpaced most of the world, even as the country's growth roars on.

headline: Australia's Schwarzer Heading to Arsenal?
summary: Mark Schwarzer, the Australia goalkeeper most recently with Fulham, may be joining Arsenal. Plus, it's time to start paying attention to Holland's team, and Paraguay's ambassador to Japan has no divided allegiances.

headline: World Cup Referees Are Under Fire
summary: FIFA is again upset about the officiating in World Cup competitions and is pledging to hold talks about the use of video replay and other technology. It's an exercise that FIFA has been through before.

headline: 7 Lessons the World Cup Offers on the Stock Market
summary: Brett Arends explains what the beautiful game can teach you about the money game.

headline: NYPD Terror Chief Won't Rank Targets
summary: The New York Police Department's incoming counterterrorism chief, Richard Daddario, won't be ranking potential terror targets in New York City.

headline: Published and Perished
summary: In "The Zeroes," Randall Lane relives his misadventures publishing magazines that burnished Wall Streeters' egos—before the fall. Edward Kosner reviews.

headline: State Workers Accept Pension Cuts
summary: Some public-sector unions, trying to avoid furloughs and layoffs, are accepting less-generous pension benefits for current workers and retirees, often for the first time in years.

headline: All Set for Her Summer in Greece
summary: In preparation for his 16-year-old daughter's summer in Greece under the auspices of the American Farm School, Ralph Gardner Jr. decides to chip in assembling a toiletry bag.

headline: Petraeus Backs Plan for Afghan Pullout
summary: During his Senate confirmation hearing, Gen. Petraeus faced stiff criticism over the U.S. timeline for troop withdrawal from Afghanistan and said he supported and agreed with the decision.

headline: Mets' Mejia Has Tear in Throwing Arm
summary: Jenrry Mejia has a posterior cuff strain in his right shoulder. Plus, a place to get your cycling fix, and Takeru Kobayashi bows out of Coney Island's hot dog contest.

headline: BP to Aid Station Owners
summary: BP is floating a financial lifeline to the owners, operators and suppliers of the gas stations around America that bear its name and have been struggling because of boycotts prompted by the Gulf spill.

headline: The SEC's Russian Roulette
summary: Over the past two years, the SEC has approved public listings for nine start-ups run by people in Ukraine or Russia, with no revenues or operations and minimal assets. Business plans ranged from renting bicycles in Kiev to selling cars in Siberia.

headline: Performance Reviews by Numbers
summary: Many U.S. companies are starting to take employee reviews out of managers' hands, instead relying on computer programs and quantifiable metrics to judge employee performance.

headline: Feds Should Fix the Real Deposit Insurance Problem
summary: Robert C. Pozen's "$100,000 is Plenty for Deposit Insurance" (op-ed, June 23) fails to identify the real risk in the current structure of deposit insurance and offers a solution that will likely result in another financial crisis.

headline: Altria, Lorillard Log Gains
summary: Boeinng and Alcoa declined as the Dow Jones Industrial Average edged lower. Gains by Intel, Coca-Cola and Wal-Mart kept losses in check.

headline: Coal Prices Rise on Accidents
summary: A string of deadly coal mining accidents around the world that have forced production cutbacks and prompted safety crackdowns is pushing up prices for coal used in steel making.

headline: Britain's Damaging Defense Cuts
summary: The Cameron government may rue the day it surrendered military options in exchange for pennies saved.

headline: Anthony B. Kim: The Seoul Stumbling Blocks on Trade
summary: President Obama risks having the U.S.-Korea free-trade agreement fall apart if he asks Korea to renegotiate it a third time.

headline: Chinese Tourists Flock to Japan
summary: Chinese tourists are to Japan today what the Japanese were to Manhattan and Honolulu during the late '80s: the single fastest-growing group of overseas travelers and the highest spenders.

headline: Plea Possible in JFK Bomb Plot
summary: A Guyanese man appears poised to plead guilty in an alleged plot to carry out a bombing at Kennedy Airport, even as the plot's alleged ringleader has asked for the case to be delayed two months.

headline: Brooklyn's Master of Strings
summary: Luthier Samuel Zygmuntowicz makes some of the world's best violins, violas and cellos from his brownstone in Park Slope.

headline: Tesla to Start Up on Nasdaq
summary: Electric-car maker Tesla Motors increased the size of its initial public offering and priced it at $17 a share, above the proposed price range.

headline: Fast Traders Face Off Against Big Investors
summary: High-speed firms and traditional investors like mutual funds are facing off in a costly battle of technology and regulatory will.

headline: Thailand Eyes Protests' Backing
summary: Thai authorities are going after businesses and entrepreneurs they say helped fund the protests that grew into a frenzy of rioting and arson in May.

headline: Flood of Gun-Rights Suits Seen
summary: The Supreme Court decision expanding gun rights will likely trigger a flood of litigation in states and cities with restrictive laws, meaning it will take years before the impact of the ruling is clear.

headline: Afghanistan: Eyes Wide Shut
summary: President Obama's ambivalence toward the war is energizing our enemies and undermining our allies.

headline: Scary Thought: Serves Going Faster
summary: After John Isner and Nicolas Mahut bludgeoned their way into the history books, observers felt that both players' serves were too good to make the match enjoyable. But what if serves still had room to get better?

headline: AL Shortstops Have Lost Their Luster
summary: Cal Ripken Jr. ushered in an era of offensive shortstops who dominated the American League a decade ago. That era seems to have passed by quickly.

headline: After Ruling, 'Sarbox' Still Law of Land
summary: A Supreme Court decision Monday means the contentious Sarbanes-Oxley legislation lives to see another day.

headline: Guinea Starts Transition to Democracy
summary: Guinea is poised to become the latest in a long line of African nations to reintroduce democracy after a period of military rule. But other African countries show how halting and problematic this transition can be.

headline: Technip Settles U.S. Bribery Charges
summary: French construction and engineering company Technip agreed to pay $338 million to settle U.S. charges that it funneled bribes to Nigerian officials to win more than $6 billion in contracts to build a liquefied-natural-gas plant.
